subject: Politics
title: Echo Chambers and Filter Bubbles
description: A 1-minute de-risking session on Echo Chambers and Filter Bubbles.

hook.text: Your news feed shows you what you already believe. Algorithms trap you in a bubble of comfortable agreement.

buildup.text: Filter bubbles form when algorithms personalize content based on your behavior, hiding opposing viewpoints.

discovery.text: Echo chambers amplify beliefs. People in them become more extreme because they only hear agreement.

twist.text: Research is mixed. Some studies find bubbles are real; others say people see more diverse views online than off.

climax.text: Even if bubbles are partial, their political effect is real. Polarization grows when people distrust outside sources.

punchline.text: Algorithms show you what you like. What you like isn't always what you need.

quiz.question: What is a filter bubble?
options: When algorithms personalize content, hiding opposing viewpoints
A physical barrier in broadcast studios
A government policy restricting news access
